title: 113_hr4128
content: The "Small Business Tax Credit Accessibility Act" aims to make the small business health care tax credit more accessible for small employers. This Act expands and modifies the credit for employee health insurance expenses of small employers. The Small Business Tax Credit Accessibility Act expands the definition of eligible small employers by increasing the employee limit from 25 to 50. It also adjusts the credit amount based on the number of employees and average wages. The Small Business Tax Credit Accessibility Act expands the definition of eligible small employers by increasing the employee limit from 25 to 50 and adjusts the credit amount based on the number of employees and average wages. The act also allows for a partially phased-out credit for insurance outside an exchange. The Small Business Tax Credit Accessibility Act expands eligibility for small employers, adjusting credit amounts based on employees and wages. It introduces a partially phased-out credit for insurance outside an exchange in 2014. The Small Business Tax Credit Accessibility Act expands eligibility for small employers, adjusting credit amounts based on employees and wages. It introduces a partially phased-out credit for insurance outside an exchange in 2014, without regard to credit periods or contribution arrangements. The employer must offer a qualified health plan to its employees through an Exchange. The health plan must provide essential health benefits and be offered by a licensed health insurance issuer in good standing in each State. Extension of Credit Period.--Paragraph (2) of section 45R(e) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the credit period. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change the consecutive taxable years requirement. The average annual wage limitation and contribution requirement are also adjusted. The cap relating to average local premiums is eliminated. Subsection (b) of section 45R of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to specify the aggregate amount of nonelective contributions made by the employer for employee health plan premiums. The availability of tax credits is extended to spouses and dependents of eligible individuals. These amendments apply to expenses incurred in taxable years starting after a certain date. The amendments apply to expenses incurred in taxable years starting after December 31, 2013.
